## Table of contents

## Forces on solid materials

### Hooke's law

When a force is applied to a spring, it will extend. Increasing the force will increase the extension up to a point where the spring becomes permanently deformed or stretched.

Plotting a graph of force against the extension gives a straight line as shown below.

Many solids behave in the same way when a force is applied. If the force and extension are proportional, it obeys Hooke&apos;s law.

<Callout emoji="âœï¸">

Hooke&apos;s law states that the tension in a spring or wire is proportional to its extension from its natural length, provided the extension is not too great.

</Callout>

This can be written in the form of an equation:

$$
F=kx
$$

<Columns left="where, ">

where $F$ is the force or tension in N;

$x$ is the extension in m; and

k is the spring constant in Nm<sup>-1</sup>.

</Columns>

Note that, as different springs and materials will need different forces to cause the same extension, their spring constants will be different.

<Callout emoji="âš¡ï¸">

The spring constant is equal to the gradient of the line on a force-extension graph.

</Callout>

<Callout emoji="âš¡ï¸">

The area under the graph is equal to the work done by the force on the object. Hence, the energy stored in a material (in the form of elastic potential energy) is:

$$
\Delta E_e = \text{work done} = \text{area of triangle} = \frac{1}{2} Fx
$$

</Callout>

Since, $F = kx$, $E = \frac{1}{2} kx^2$

### The Young modulus

The problem with using the elastic constant is that its value is different for each specimen of a material that has a different shape and size. A more useful quantity is **the Young modulus**, which is **independent** of the material's length and width. This enables a fair comparison of the stiffness of different materials. The Young modulus is defined as:

$$
\text{Young modulus, } E = \frac{\text{stress}}{\text{strain}} = \frac{\sigma}{\varepsilon}
$$

<div className="flex">
<div>

**stress**, $\sigma = \frac{\text{force}}{\text{area}}$ &rarr; $\sigma = \frac{F}{a}$

**strain**, $\varepsilon = \frac{\text{extension}}{\text{original length}}$ &rarr; $\varepsilon = \frac{l}{\Delta l}$

</div>

<div>

units: Nm<sup>-2</sup> or Pa

units: none ($l/l = 1$)

</div>
</div>

Hence, the unit for the Young modulus is **Nm<sup>-2</sup>** (or Pa) &mdash; the same as the unit for stress.

So, substituting these two definitions for stress and strain into the Young modulus equation:

$$
E = \frac{F / A}{\Delta l / l} = \frac{Fl}{\Delta l A}
$$

## Types of solid

Solids can be arranged into three main classifications.

1. Crystaline
2. Amorphous
3. Polymeric

<Callout emoji="ðŸ’¡">

The classification depends on the order and structure of the atoms and molecules in the material.

</Callout>

### Crystaline

These solids have short and long-range order i.e. there is a **regular** pattern of atoms (or sometimes molecules) over a distance of at least 100 atomic diameters.

Almost all metals are examples of polycrystalline solids, as well as many minerals e.g. salt, where there are many small crystals called **grains**. Each grain has a different orientation. This makes the structure very strong. The line between each grain is known as the **grain boundary**.

### Amorphous

The term amorphous (meaning &apos;without shape or form&apos;) is used to describe solid substances in which there is little or no long-range order in the arrangement of the particles. It can be likened to an instantaneous or &apos;frozen&apos; picture of the internal structure of a liquid.

In practice there are few examples of solids with such totally random structures, however, glass or brick are given as examples in which there may be ordered clusters of atoms (much smaller than the &apos;small&apos; crystals found in polycrystalline materials like metals).

### Polymeric

Polymers consist of very long chains of carbon atoms bonded to hydrogen and other atoms. Polymers can be **natural** (e.g. cellulose, protein, rubber, etc.) or **synthetic** (e.g. polyethane , polythene, polystyrene, nylon, etc.).

<div className="flex justify-center mt-6">
  <svg
    width="578"
    height="190"
    viewBox="0 0 578 190"
    fill="none"
    xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
  >

      stroke="currentColor"
      stroke-width="2.4"
    />
    <path

Initially stress and strain are proportional; the material obeys Hooke&apos;s law.

$P$ is the limit of proportionality, where the metal no longer obeys Hooke&apos;s law.

$E$ is the elastic limit of the material; this corresponds to the maximum stress that can be applied where the material will return to its original length. Up to this point the material experiences elastic strain. Any extension above this point will cause plastic strain; the atoms in the material will begin to move past each other and the material will be permanently deformed.

$Y$ is the yield point &mdash; a small increase in the load on the material will cause a large extension. This means that the material is ductile.

At $X$ the material will break. The corresponding stress is known as the breaking stress.

### Plastic deformation and edge dislocations

As a metal crystal forms, edge dislocations will frequently appear where a plane of atoms will not be complete before the next plane, as shown in the diagram below.

Note that at $D$, there is a dislocation in the regular array of atoms.

When a force is applied to the metal, the bonds between the atoms will stretch. If the stress is below the elastic limit, when the force is no longer applied, the bonds will return to their original length. However, if the force applied is large enough, the bonds around D are stretched further and will snap, causing the dislocation to move, as shown in the diagram below.

As long as the force is applied, this process will repeat until the dislocation moves to the edge of the crystal or grain.

This will make the crystal longer as a result of the apparent movement of one plane of atoms past another. As metals contain many edge dislocations, this can result in a large increase in strain with only a little stress. This is shown above the yield point on the previous stress-strain graph.

In order to strengthen metals, impurities are introduced to stop this process. For example, steel contains approximately 99% iron atoms and a comparatively small number of carbon atoms. These atoms create a barrier to dislocation movement.

### Necking

Necking is the fracture of a rod or wire of a ductile material is preceded by local thinning, which increases the stress.

This is caused by an increased number of edge dislocations, causing the wire to lengthen. As the volume of the wire is constant, this causes the cross-sectional area to decrease. Therefore, the stress at that point will increase until the material breaks.

The image below shows a metal rod where ductile fracture has occurred. Note how it has become narrower around the fracture.

<div className="flex justify-center mt-6">
  <Image src={imageOne} width={800} height={438} alt="Necking example" />
</div>

As shown by the graph, stress and strain are proportional for brittle materials. This means that they obey Hooke&apos;s law and are elastic. However, the breaking stress for a brittle material is generally much smaller than the breaking stress of a ductile material such as copper.

### Brittle fracture

The breaking stress of a brittle material is low due to microscopic cracks in the material.

<div className="flex justify-center mt-6">
  <svg
    width="472"
    height="255"
    viewBox="0 0 472 255"
    fill="none"
    xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
  >
    <path
      d="M1.30035 113.647V1.6947H219.53L229.332 26.4584L239.65 1.6947H470.262V113.647H1.30035Z"
      stroke="currentColor"
      stroke-width="2.4"
    />
    <path
      d="M1.30035 253.427V141.474H219.53L229.332 221.918L239.65 141.474H470.262V253.427H1.30035Z"
      stroke="currentColor"
      stroke-width="2.4"
    />
  </svg>
</div>

When tension is applied to a brittle material, the stress at the tip of a crack is high. This causes the crack to elongate and results in even higher stress at the tip. This means the crack will continue to propagate through the material, leading to failure known as **brittle fracture**.

In order to increase the breaking stress for a brittle material, two methods are used:

One method is to **reduce the number of cracks on the surface of a material**. For example, thinner glass fibres have fewer cracks per unit area as they have cooled more quickly. As the number of cracks is lower, they will not propagate as readily.

Another solution is to form the material under **compression**; this means that the cracks do not open up and propagate. Examples of this include **toughened glass** and **prestressed concrete**. The latter is where the concrete is poured around steel rods which are under tension. When the tension is released, the concrete will be under compression.

</div>

_Note, a force-extension graph and stress-strain graph will be the same shape._

As shown above, it is only approximately linear with small extensions. Therefore, it will only obey Hooke&apos;s law when the force (or stress) is small.

The reason for this shape is due to the **polymeric** structure of rubber. Rubber consists of long chains of carbon atoms which are tangled around each other. Untangling requires a large force (because of cross-links), and so the gradient is steep to begin with.

When further stress is applied, these chains begin to straighten. The rotation of the bonds between the atoms does not require much force, so a large extension occurs with a small force. Once they are straightened and continue to extend the rubber, the bonds must stretch. This requires more force, resulting in the increase in gradient of the graph.

Once the force is released, the vibration of the molecules will cause them to become tangled again and the rubber will return to its original length.

### Hysterisis

The curve for the extension of a material is often different to the curve for the contraction. This is especially true for a polymeric material, because of the cross-links.

The graph below shows how the force-extension curve for rubber differs when plotting the loading and unloading of rubber.

Looking at the force-extension graph for a rubber band, the extension curve has little extension at the start. This is because all those cross-links between the molecules are making it difficult to stretch.

Once fully stretched, these cross-links have re-attached at new positions, and when the tension is now slowly decreased, they again make it harder for the molecules to (initially) pass over each other, i.e. rubber band doesn&apos;t contract as easily as expected.

The net effect is that there&apos;s work done internally, a bit like friction. This work done over one extension-contraction cycle is released as heat, and its value is equal to the area between the two curves.

This is an example of hysteresis, and is the reason an elastic band will become hot if it is repeatedly stretched and released several times in quick succession.
